value.0:
Nearest to Amia of all the Ruathym Jarldoms, Fort Wiltun stands on a solitary cliff high above the gray beaches of the Sea of Swords. The banner of Fort Wiltun is the Raven, which hangs from the walls of all Wiltun-protected lands. The Wardens of Wiltun, an oathbound group of warriors and guards sworn to protect the Ruathym realm under its rightful chieftain, retain the martial hand of the Wiltun jarldom in all of its territories. Ruathym's mariners often work gladly in Wiltun's navy, which features one of the largest armadas in the northern seas, rivaled only by the Cordorian navy, which escorts several wealthy trade ships past the Ruathym coast, as well as Ruathym's sworn enemy, the nefarious Luskans, whom through piracy and arcane trickery have instilled in the people of Ruathym a great mistrust for magic. Very few magicians live in Ruathym without fear of superstitious reprisal, and no Luskan ever leaves Ruathym alive.

For Wiltun is easily reached by sailing ship and serves as a major nexus for many other destinations throughout the Sea of Swords and the Trackless Sea. As such, many adventurers have the opportunity to earn some coin and some prestige by working in Wiltun or abroad in Wiltun's interests, as well as the opportunity to spend it in several storefronts. So long as they don't mind paying taxes to Fort Wiltun.

Nes'ek is mostly a Lathanderan settlement in the center of the Ankh'remun Desert in Khem. The Church of Hoar and of Kelemvor now both also reside in it. The church of Lathander is on strained terms with the clergy of the Mulhorandi pantheon. This conflict originates through the race for more followers and the claims of both sides to be the true faith of Khem. The Church of Hoar often even stands in direct confrontation with the faithful of the Eight, most notably the faith of Anhur.

The township is also often caught up in the struggles between the Bedine and Minotaurs. The clergy of Lathander often tasks adventurers with the job of putting down the Sand Minotaurs. Nes'ek is reached via a portal on the top of the keep in Fortress Wiltun, or through the portal lens of the travel lamps around Amia and joining areas of the mainland.

L'Obsul is a confusing mess of a settlement like many found throughout the uncharted Underdark. The settlement is designed around vertically-tiered caverns all connected by a pulley system operated by slaves. While difficult for many to pronounce (and it would be wisest not to try), L'Obsul stands for "door" in the tongue of the drow and the drow are the true leaders of this unruly place. House Zau'tar, a noble and prideful group of drow, control the political and economic institutions of L'Obsul yet are not above dealing with others races that are willing to work quietly under the table. Almost anyone is allowed into their complex, but not everyone comes out; those who stay in L'Obsul learn to be wary of its delicate caste system. Anyone can end up in chains.

Many tunnels lead away from L'Obsul in many different directions and very few of them are safe, providing fertile hunting grounds for adventurers of varied experience, everything from rats to the basest of kobolds, as well as mindflayers and beholders for those seeking greater glory in The Deeper Dark. It's also rumored that a host of noble drow have occupied one of the larger caverns, driven out the previous inhabitants and are now barring access to anyone not of their House.


((WARNING: If your character is not an Underdark character, take extreme care in journeying here. The Underdark is no place for sacrificial Surfacer fodder.))
Put items that you not longer want or need in the trash. They will vanish permanently once the lid is closed and cannot be recovered, so be certain about your choice to dispose of them.

Nestled on the edge of Benwick Bay on the northeast coast of the island, Kampo's Storehouse has been the meeting point of outlaws, smugglers, and lawless travelers with pasts too circumspect for them to reside in nearby Kohlingen or even distant Cordor. That isn't to say the Storehouse caters exclusively to the island's most nefarious characters, but rather it caters to anyone with coin and a drive to earn more of it. Kampo has made an arrangement with Amian Cart Services to guarantee that they will stop by to supply and give passage to anyone willing to pay for it.

Kampo is a devout follower of Waukeen and an advocate of tolerance. Not much is known about the half-orc's past but the man accumulated enough wealth to establish his trade house on the main thoroughfare of trade along the bay. Recently, the nearby Eilistraeen Shrine funded the refurbishment of the Storehouse with the assistance of adventurers following a bar brawl that devastated the structure. Golems now defend the Storehouse alongside Kampo's own hired guards, acting as a deterrent to anyone foolish enough to "pull that crap again".

Anyone looking for information, goods or mercenaries can find them at the Storehouse. If not, Kampo will know where to look.

Moonpier is on the western coast of Amia, separated from Southport territory by the Delta freelands and the bandits who dominate the highway connecting the fishing village and the island's trade capitol. Though it was originally established over a century ago as an outpost and secondary port to supplement trade and growth, the powers-that-were never saw fit to truly exercise any authority in the village. Moonpier's inhabitants support themselves on the fishing trade and local agriculture.

Throughout the years, they were often forced to fight their own battles against pirates, bandits, and orcish raiders who descended upon them from the inland hills. Eventually they elected their own mayor both out of a necessity for local government and as a statement of autonomy. Only once did Southport's predecessor attempt to assert its authority over Moonpier, but the political annexation was weak in execution and merely bolstered the reality that Moonpier is truly an independent community.

The village has very little to offer to tourists, but adventurers who travel through Amia find a more welcoming atmosphere in Moonpier than in other settlements, despite the town's obvious troubles. The local militia is a strong and dedicated one, but ultimately friendly to adventurers provided they observe customs. Some suggest this has something to do with the militia being populated by a few former adventure-seekers. The worship of Selune is the predominant faith in Moonpier, and the village was once known to support an open-air temple to the goddess of the moon. The citizens have long been dedicated to the religion, save for a troubled year of Banite occupation, and desire to grow again in faith.

Moonpier is easily and safely reached by sai, cart services, or the portal system from the Triumvir, but intrepid travelers may take their chances traveling north from the Delta on foot.

Fort Cystana is part of the Kingdom of Kohlingen. It is located on the northwest coast of Amia. The people of the small, developing city of Fort Cystana once hailed from the great Holy City of Kohlingen, which is located on the northeastern coast of the isle and has since become a Duchy of its own within the kingdom.

Frontier's Rest is located just north of Southport and is home to the Wave & Serpent Adventuring Guild. A small "suburb" town, Frontier's Rest is largely self-sufficient and carefully protected by the Guildhouse. They are, however, close with their neighbors. Much of Southport's food comes from Frontier's Rest. It is also part of the Kingdom of Cetha, which is made up of Southport, Frontier's Rest, and Ridgewood.

Southport has known a few names over the generations: the Gem of the Trackless Sea, the City of Tolerance, the City of Water, and the Commonwealth, when the citizens, aggrieved with the noble caste, politically dismantled the establishment and instituted a citizens' government. In spite of the city's instability, one core factor has ever remained consistent: the port city has always been a hotspot that draws trade both foreign and domestic to its streets and market halls, so much so that the city once housed one of the largest Waukeenar churches in Toril. A great calamity now sees most of the former jewel of the Trackless Sea sunk to the bottom of the ocean. In an effort to curb their resultant vulnerability, they formed an alliance with Frontier's Rest and Ridgewood and came together as the Kingdom of Cetha.

Visitors to the island tend to reach Southport by sea travel and dock at the ports in its western district, where they can find cheap housing and access to nearby shops. Merchants and tourists are the city's primary visitors, each drawn distinctly by the things the island of Amia has to offer them, with Southport often being their first taste of the island. The rough and rowdy locals often make guests gravitate to the more peaceful and friendly Frontier's Rest in due time, however.

But adventurers are drawn to the island in abundance as well by the promise of wealth, glory, and adventure. While Frontier's Rest and Southport are surrounded by hazards - coastal marshes of dangerous animals and bandits to the west, warrior tribes of goblins and orcs to the north, and stranger creatures along the shorelines to the east - it is highly defensible. Although they say that extremely large reptiles make for something of an exception to this rule.

An honored place of healing and care for all those under the good graces of the gods to find much-needed respite from the many woes that inflict the good citizens of Amia. Salandra welcomes all those talented in the healing arts to seek out her temple and join in bringing relief to the sick and needy who come in search of cures and healing.

Salandra the Healer is a demigod under Ilmaters service. Once a mortal priestess of the Crying God on the island of Amia, she dedicated her life to the treatment of illness and eradication of undeath. Eventually, she faced a martyrs fate when stopping a devastating malady, and Ilmater saw fit to reward her devotion with divinity.

Salandras temples are few and far between. The oldest one is located here on Amia, her home island. There are a handful of other small temples on Toril: on the Moonshaes, somewhere in the Dalelands, and in Tethyr. Small shrines exist in a few Ilmateri temples.

The primary duty of Salandrans is to treat wounds and cure illnesses, offering a helping hand to anyone in need. The clergy members are renowned for their skill with herbs, surgery, and other forms of treatment for ailments of both body and spirit. Every servant is expected to learn the basics of medicine. Mundane forms of healing are preferred to those of divine nature whenever possible.

The beautiful elven enclave of Winya Ravana, located in the verdant Nexus Hills and upstream to the Nexus Falls, is a uniquely elven blend of civilized structure sharing the same space as natural features. The City of the People is a sapphire and emerald paradise, strewn with lush copses of oak and aspen, cool clear streams, and everywhere the sacred magic of the elves. Winya Ravana, which in elven means "new forests", is most easily reached by taking a cart to the Nexus Hills and then ascending the bluffs that form the breathtaking Nexus Falls, where the currents from the citys many pure springs coarse down into a valley to form the Minmir River. Through the mist and spray atop the Falls, one may witness the most magnificent sunsets on Amia.

Winya Ravana itself consists of two areas: the Outer Sanctum and the Inner Sanctum. These two sancta are connected by bridge over a crystalline lake which feeds the Nexus. The Outer Sanctum is open to kin and friends of the People alike and offers much to see and do: situated in the center of this sanctum looms an enormous and ancient tree that covers the Market Square. Here you may also find a talented elven smith as well as the Iron Butterfly Inn, famed for its elven cuisine and a lush apple orchard. The Outer Sanctum is also a superb area for fishing.

To the north across the bridge lies the Inner Sanctum, the spiritual center of Winya Ravana. This sacred field is open only to the sons and daughters of The Seldarine. Guests of the People, however, are welcome in company of kin. Shrines to each member of the Seldarine can be found both inside and outside the grand Temple of Corellon. There are also a few tree houses here where a keen eye may spy a sly-but-friendly fey creature. The Inner Sanctum also holds an archery range and a bathhouse and lounge area between the spiritual centers of the Temple.

"All roads lead to The Dale" is a popular saying amongst Amian traders. Due to its prime central location on the island, The Dale is a waypoint and rest stop for caravans and travelers using the trade roads across the Amian island. The village is populated almost exclusively by hin, though other fairfolk races such as gnomes, dwarves, and smaller fey are welcomed as citizens. Agriculture plays a key part in the Dale. The apple orchard in particular is well known. Wayfarers often visit the Hin Inn, a taller-friendly establishment that boasts some of Amia's best food and drinks from around the island, as well as a tradition of folk music. The Inn is more than a place for drink and merriment, though; with people traveling through The Dale from all points on the island and with the locals' penchant for storytelling, the gossip is great. Before they leave visitors are encouraged to resupply with the village's many homegrown goods, from arcane goods to healing supplies and traveling goods.

The Dale's centrality has a downside, though. Orcs to the south, trolls to the east, and mylocks on the west pose constant threats to the otherwise peaceful village, necessitating a strong hin militia and vigilant border camps. The Amia Forest spreads to the north and is otherwise peaceful thanks to the Oakmist Vale druid grove nestled deep in the trees. Unless you stray from the path and encounter the wild creatures that roam near there.

Boredom is the only thing unwelcome in The Dale, so playful tricks and pranks for a good laugh at someone's expense aren't uncommon. Beware to those of ill humor.

The island of Amia lies at the farthest edge of the Sea of Swords, directly along what Sword Coast merchants call the Trackless Trade Route that carries merchants and their goods to and from foreign ports like Kara-Tur, Maztica, and Chult. Amia and its small port city of Southport is a primary stopping point for trade ships moving through the open ocean, but where merchants enjoy the island for its money exchange, trade opportunities, luxury markets and sometimes a nice seaside vacation, many others are drawn to the island for its promise of adventure.

It may have been a canny move on behalf of a tourism expert, but Amia developed a reputation as an adventurer's paradise generations ago and is still characterized that way to this day on mainland Faerun. Adventurers that come to Amia almost always arrive by large passenger vessel in the port city of Southport and find themselves just north in Frontier's Rest, where they heed the call of the Wave and Serpent Adventuring Guild. From there they can travel by ship or by cart to most civilized points of the island, and by foot to the island's wilder frontier.

Other unique communities exist on Amia for those seeking something the major settlements lack. The Crouching Lemur monastery in the foothills of the Skull Crags offers a monastic living for those who eschew the excesses of the major trade-influenced cities. Likewise, for those dedicated wholly to the balance of nature, the Oakmist Vale druid's grove north of the halfling home known as The Dale makes an excellent haven.

Further up the coast along the waters of Silent Bay are temple grounds dedicated to Salandra, a regional goddess of healing. The Salandran Temple is visited by wealthy nobles and personalities from as far away as mainland Faerun, and the temple grounds have gotten the reputation as a livewell resort for individuals with ailments physical, mental, and spiritual that traditional magic cannot cure. Sellswords and other mercenaries are welcome in the Mercenary's Camp nestled within the Quagmire swamps. West from there, the small Duchy of Fort Cystana lies on an outcropping which some say mysteriously fell from the sky and landed on the northern coast.

In the harsh environment of the Shadow Plane, there is an oasis of civilization called Shadowscape. The city is magically protected, shielding visitors and citizens alike from the worst effects of living on the plane. Amians can reach Shadowscape through a planar rift located in the Trummels of the Amia Forest, but only after traveling through some dangerous wilderness. Smaller rifts are rumored to be somewhere in Brogendenstein and Endirs Point in the Frozenfar, however these lead to more dangerous areas of the plane that are outside the safety of the citys walls. The Keeper of Shadows hosts a city with everything you might need. In the market square there are merchants carrying wares of magical shadesteel, including a special outlet that caters to dedicated Shadow Walkers, and somewhere in the city is a discreet temple to Mask.

The city is home to the notorious Three Steps Academy. The Academy, as it is more commonly called, offers elite training in the art of shadowdancing. Dancers of any proficiency level, from beginners to masters, are welcome and have the opportunity to also learn about shadow plane theory and science, shade mastery, and more advanced forms of the art. For visitors wanting to take in the everpresent night life of Shadowscape, the Drunk Dancer Inn promises luxurious lodging, exquisite brews and refreshment, and decadent entertainment. This glittering jewel is conveniently located in the northwest corner on the citys second tier and commands an impressive view over the her dark beauty.

Amia is not alone out there where the Sea of Swords meets the Trackless Sea. Those who go to the island seeking adventure can find other opportunities within a few days of sea travel. Nearest to Amia is the grim island of Ruathym and its fractious jarldoms: Wiltun, which claims one of the most powerful navies in the Sea of Swords and which regularly wars with Luskan trade ships; Caraigh, a mineral rich area of Ruathym beset by the sins of its past; and Ostland, the only truly fertile landscape in Ruathym. There is also Forrstakkr, a backwater island that features some of the most beautiful and regular aurora borealis in the world, as well as Barak Runedar, home to dwarves who were so long ago run from their ancient undermountain home, but have long sought to reclaim what is rightfully theirs.

Explorers can also find adventure on the northern coast of the mainland in the Frozenfar region, making port in Endir's Point and exploring the surrounding hinterlands and other points of interest like the ironically named Fort Summer and the lost dwarven citadel of Barak Tungstuk. Particularly canny adventurers abandon the surface altogether and travel underground to explore the dangerous depths of the Underdark, where the denizens have built civilizations like the slave colony of L'Obsul and the mysterious Nec'perya, a drow enclave nestled in the middle of dangerous faezress.

Ruathym's largest jarldom is Ostland, located on the northeastern coast of Ruathym. The southernmost port of Osthavn is a traveler's first destination, one of many shipping destinations in the Sea of Swords, and from there they can travel east to the boglands of the Frightmere and then north to the mountainous regions of North Ostland. Having spent the greater amount of time in constant warfare, the total region of Ostland is starved of natural resources used to fuel the conflict and is nearly depleted of gross product. Without brave men and women to fight its war, Ostlands conflicts bear no expectations of a peaceful solution, so mercenaries may find plenty of work in the jarldom. Ostland's countryside is also a draw for botanists and other life scientists for the strange fruit that grows there and the unusual wildlife. Rangers and druids have also started to take an interest in the land, as well, and rumors persist of a strange druidic circle somewhere in the wilderness.

Captain Guston's northbound ship sails passengers to the isle of Barak Runedar, where they'll be welcomed by the industrious dwarves of the frozen wilds. The dwarven port and citadel are nestled on the southeastern side of Brogendenstein's two mountains, Khazat Murr and the larger Grumdek Murr. Barak Runedar touts a healthy trade in the riches of the earth, chiefly gemstones and mineral ores, as well as expert stonework architecture shaped by skilled dwarven crafters who live and work under the watchful and ever present gaze of the dwarven pantheon, the Mordinsamman. Dwarves are known for their penchant for ale and spirits as they are for their steadfastness and love of a good fight; at the right hour of the day, both can be found in the renowned citadal brewery.

Whereas Barak Runedar offers warm hearths, stout ale, and camaraderie, the rest of Brogendenstein is a place of wild and unpredictable danger. Big game hunting is major draw to the frozen valleys and the tundra where hungry, territorial northern beasts such as the violent Great Northern Bear, the elusive Northern Sabertooth Tigers, the indomitable Mega-Bison and the bloodthirsty Northern Dodo roam and hunt. Orcs, mindless barbarians, frost giants, howling yeti, grim fey, snow beasts, and a spire full of fire giants hound hunters and adventurers the whole of the way. Old paths through the snowy forests and up to Grumdek Murr's peak are treacherous to any foreign traveler, and even locals avoid the northwest side of the mountains, a frozen wasteland beaten hard by the icy winds from the Trackless Sea.

The authorities of Barak Runedar insisted upon the following disclaimer: "Follow the laws of the Barak Runedar, respect our heritage and gods, ignorance of the law excuses it not. Do these and enjoy all that Barak Runedar and Brogendenstein have to offer. The Council of Barak Runedar thanks you and greets you warmly to our halls."

Endir's Point is the end of the line for many mainland travelers scouring the Sword Coast, some from as far away as Calimsham. Located on the icy tip of the Frozenfar's coast, Endir's Point is reached by sailing vessel by most and on foot only by the bravest or most foolish, such as founder Endir himself, for whom conflicting stories of courage and idiocy abound. Like many communities near to the Spine of the World and the great glacier, mining is an important local industry in Endir's Point. The presence of a rift to the Shadow Plane has started trade between Endir's Point and the shadow plane city of Shadowscape, affording the small village more amenities than most villages in the Frozenfar. Travelers almost always visit the shrine to Shaundakul to venerate the god of the roads and then to have some warm mead or Ralten's Special at the local inn and tavern, Ralten's Retreat.

Adventurers who travel into the hinterlands around Endir's Point should be wary of the bloodthirsty trolls, orcs, ogres, and wintery fey that dominate the wild. But in spite of the danger they present, there are many things to be found in the abandoned Fort Summer to the east, the frozen lake and the ruins of Barak Tungstak to the north, and a grand Ice Palace of Auril to the west.

Unfortunately, Forrstakkr is not a major tourist attraction. Nor is it a major trade destination. The hard-working and disciplined people of Forrstakkr's only major port of Howness, however, have made the icy island a reliable manufacturer of good. Pelts hunted from local wildlife make excellent leather and hide for local tailors, while the tall pines of the Niflwood provide carpenters with adequate lumber for furnishings. An ancient glacier tore mineral from the earth ages ago and now the natives mine iron and make good and sturdy steel parts from it.

The major draw in Forrstakkr is for hunters, adventurers, and man against nature survivalists. The wilderness on the island is both dangerous and beautiful, featuring untamed wildlife such as winter wolves who hunt in packs among snow-draped conifers and snow leopards hiding in the glacial ridges colored with the unique colored lights that manifest in the sky. Howness locals are very isolationist and keep strangers at arm's length. The mistrust comes from a combination of merchant shysters trying to take advantage of them in the past as well as devout Aurilities that bring winter's wrath to their wooden barricades all too often. Visitors can also visit a monastery on the eastern edge of the island, and rumors abound of a dragon lurking in one of the caverns on Mt. Kjarnales.

Caraigh is a larger island east of Ruathym, an island born down by tragedy. No lord has ruled the isle for a generation; instead, leadership has passed through many unuccesful hands, each time the island's people left to fend for themselves against the sins of the past. The land is severely tainted by a dark curse and the undead walk its wooded meadows after sunset. The people in the small village of Ceyren's Mill live private and detached lives isolated from the tainted countryside and suspicious of strangers who come from the wilderness, but their rustic living has a certain charm to it for people seeking a simple life of simple tasks. Travelers can reach Caraigh by ship, and Ceyren's Mill is a short and relatively safe walk to the north, provided you travel by day.

Deeper in the badlands of the island lie ruins in old druidic fashion, said to be the remains of the followers of Eldath. Their disappearance remains a mystery, as do many things on the island. Other destinations are not so mysterious, but are certainly unique, such as a lighthouse/observatory and a sanatorium on the northern bluffs of the island, or the abandoned hunting lodge once used by a local lord and a nearby ominous blackstone fortress at the heart of the island.

The Wave & Serpent Adventuring Guild is where most adventurers congregate when they first arrive on Amia. Here, you will find a multitude of shops and personalities, as well as information about the island and direct access to a mythal forge.

The Guild is led by a group of seasoned Guildmasters who often give out quests or jobs of varying levels of difficulty. Come by often to keep up to date on the latest offerings!

This statue will take you to a variety of different portals for faction start locations on Amia. They require faction-specific keys or items to use, so there is no need to enter this statue if you are not part of a faction with a key and unique starting location.
(Description coming soon! This is a settlement for monster races! Goblins, Hobgoblins, Kobolds, Orcs, Orogs, Ogrillons, etc.)

Zanshibon is located in the 363rd Layer of the Abyss and is ruled by the demon Paush. All manner of beings are allowed to enter Zanshibon, but they must abide by the Lord's rules, which essentially mean that whatever he says goes.

Adventurers often travel to this layer of the Abyss to cut through the hordes of demons in the abyssal wastes. Paush allows this, as it serves his purposes well enough and brings him both amusement and prosperity in the way of trade within the city bazaar.

Insulting Paush in any way is highly discouraged for anyone who is fond of their mortal soul.

The City of Kohlingen has seen many trials throughout the years. Beset by dragons at least once a decade, the city finally fell in fire and shadow for all its efforts to stand against the wicked. Now, it is being rebuilt anew, a Duchy within the larger Kingdom of Kohlingen.

[NEUTRAL SURFACE STARTING LOCATION]

This will take you to the Wave & Serpent Guildhouse!

This Guildhouse is located in the Kingdom of Cetha, within the area of Frontier's Rest. This is located on the Surface and is a suitable neutral starting location for most of our available races. Humans, elves, halflings, etc. Monsters and Underdark creatures are largely not allowed.

The following races are not able to enter:

- Orcs
- Drow
- Trolls
- Orogs
- Gnolls
- Undead
- Yuan-Ti
- Ogrillons
- Lizardfolk
- Goblinoids
- Full-blooded Fiends

[NEUTRAL UNDERDARK STARTING LOCATION]

This will take you to L'Obsul!

This settlement is located in the Underdark and is comprised of many different Underdark races in a large trading city. It is a suitable starting location for Underdark races and most surface races are not allowed to use this banner.

The following playable races are able to enter:

- Orcs
- Drow
- Orogs
- Gnolls
- Goblins
- Kobolds
- Duergar
- Ogrillons
- Lizardfolk
- Bugbears
- Svirfneblin
- Hobgoblins

A tropical island located to the southwest of Amia, Obsidian Isle holds a checkered history layered with good and evil. Currently in the process of being explored and settled by the once-refugees of the Enclave of Tarkuul, Obsidian Isle is a lavish paradise which holds a more nefarious undertone.

[EVIL SURFACE STARTING LOCATION]

This will take you to the Obsidian Isle!

This settlement is located on an island to the southwest of Amia island. Once the lair of a family of bronze dragons, it has now been claimed by the remnants of an enclave who seek to make their own mark.

There are no blanket racial restrictions for using this banner, but there are some other local laws you should mind before you enter. The following are not permitted on the Obsidian Isle:

- Metallic Dragons
- Metallic Half-Dragons
- Followers of Bahamut or Cyric
- Far Realms Cultists
- Demon Cultists
- Personnel from the following entities:
    - Kingdom of Kohlingen
    - Harpers
    - Winya Ravana
    - The Riptide
    - Iron Company/Wanderer's Legion

[GOOD SURFACE STARTING LOCATION]

This will take you to Fort Cystana!

Fort Cystana is the Capital of the Kingdom of Kohlingen, a nation of devout paladins, holy priests, and goodly magical creatures. Following the tenets of the Triad and Bahamut, the people of the Kingdom of Kohlingen seek to be a beacon of light in time of darkness and chaos.

There are no blanket racial restrictions for using this banner, but there are some other local laws you should mind before you enter. The following are not permitted in Fort Cystana:

- Shadovar
- Blackguards
- Pale masters
- Half-fiends or fiends
- Chromatic dragon kin
- Followers of evil deities
- Members of any Lolthite house
- Associates of the following:
    - Zhentarim
    - The Obsidian Isle
    - Cult of the Dragon
    - Red Wizards of Thay
